properties.grant_description: Penn State University seeks funding to support its 2009 Natural Gas Summit entitled, “Planning for Progress - Infrastructure and Water in the Marcellus Shale.” The Summit will address the challenges, opportunities, and related actions associated with natural gas leasing and development. Some of the issues to be addressed are: water use and disposal, regional infrastructure development, issues for local governments, identification of local economic opportunities, and other legal issues. The intent is to help stakeholders make informed, educated decisions that best suit the needs of the region.

The PA Council of Trout Unlimited seeks funding for their ninth Keystone Coldwater Conference entitled “Responsible Energy Development: Protecting our Coldwater Resources.” This conference will address streamside buffers, water chemistry, in-stream habitat, biodiversity, stormwater runoff, and will explore environmental threats caused by energy extraction and conversion derived from both conventional and alternative energy sources and how to protect our coldwater resources. Participation at this year's event is expected to exceed 300. Handouts and presentations will be available at http://www.coldwaterheritage.org/coldwaterconference.htm.

The Rose Valley Mill Creek Watershed Association seeks funding to support its 4th Annual Cane Pole Fishing Derby, a day-long event that includes: fishing instruction by seasoned fishermen, educational programs on the watershed and Rose Valley Lake, and a lake shore litter clean-up.

The Snyder County Conservation District seeks funding to create a campaign to form a Mahantango Creek Watershed Association. The campaign would consist of putting “admat” style place mats into two restaurants in the headwaters of Mahantango Creek.

Stream Restoration, Inc. seeks funding to be used as awards to watershed groups during the state-wide celebration of the 10th anniversary of Growing Greener. These funds, in combination with the contribution of an anonymous donor, will be distributed to 16 different watershed groups state-wide.
The Toby Creek Watershed Association seeks funding to keep the Blue Valley Acid Mine Drainage Treatment Plant in operation. This plant eliminates AMD impacts in 7 miles of the Clarion River.
properties.project_description: AMD treatment facility that raises fish.

properties.grant_description: The Westmoreland Conservation District seeks funding to support their strategic planning process to be guided by the Bayer Center for Nonprofit Management.

The Westmoreland County Sportsmen’s League seeks funding to supplement the cost of its annual conservation school to be held at Keystone State Park. The goal of the program is to help each participant acquire the necessary skills and knowledge to work in and develop environmental projects in their home areas, as well as instilling leadership skills which will help them to address pressing environmental problems before all levels of government.

The Western PA Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation seeks funding to maximize the reach of the 2009 PA Statewide Conference on Abandoned Mine Reclamation. These funds will keep the registration fee low and encourage the attendance of the many volunteer-based watershed organizations.

The Western PA Coalition for Abandoned Mine Reclamation seeks funding to professionally reproduce the game, “Mining for Coal” created by Wil Taylor of the Jenning’s Environmental Center. The game is designed to educate young children about coal mining.

The Westmoreland Earth Day Committee seeks funding to support the 8th Annual Westmoreland Earth Day themed “Living Simple.” The mission of the event is to demonstrate the connections that exist between members of the community and local natural resources. Westmoreland Earth Day has touched nearly 13,000 people since the first event in 2002.

A 350 foot stretch of Raccoon Creek that is severely impacted by stream channel misconfiguration is leading to excessive erosion and downstream deposition. This was the site of a "Municipality Streambank Workshop," where local road crews and leaders learned how to perform streambank stabilization. The project is intended to stabilize bank erosion, encourage natural deposition of gravel bar forming materials, and assist in creating suitable aquatic habitat and promote riffle/pool sequences.

Years of straightening and manipulating the flow of Cowanshannock Creek has created an unstable flow regime. This unnatural stream alignment is causing excessive lateral channel migration, undercutting and sloughing of banks, and loss of prime agricultural land. Working from two plans outlining a need for stream channel stabilization, the group partnered with David Beale, Armstrong County Watershed Specialist, who developed an aggressive, resourceful, and cost efficient mitigation plan. Pre-construction the stream was migrating nearly one-half foot annually--resulting in 20 tons of sedimentation. The project has minimized erosion. It is estimated the site will yield 0.3 tons this year.

Spring Run is a unique limestone watershed with sustained limestone-originating spring flow and consistent water temperature. Though the waterways within the watershed support aquatic life, the streams are not without impairment. An assessment of the watershed showed elevated nitrate levels, excessive sedimentation, bank sloughing/failure, direct stream access to cattle, and poorly developed buffers. This project intends to restore 3000 linear feet of stream bank.

Many studies have identified the Shaft #1 discharge as a primary source of pollution to Sandy Lick Creek. Iron deposition significantly degrades the aquatic habitat within the stream. Treatment will consist of Maelstrom Oxidizer Treatment System, a patented process held by Donald Budeit of Environmental Solutions. This technology was chosen because it reduces treatment system's footprint to one-acre and it is modular - allowing for future expansion.

The Uncommon Grounds Cafe was started by Capt. John Stanley, a  missionary of Church Army USA to help revitalize the depressed steel town of Aliquippa, PA. The Spring Street Recovery Project is an effort to prevent flooding of the Spring Street trailer park. The goal is to rehabilitate a small wetland that is currently home to thousands of rotting railroad ties, stabilize streambanks, replace old pipes with HDPE pipe and french drains to contain future runoff. The wetland rehabilitation will provide educational opportunities while the stabilization will protect residents of the Spring Street trailer park from future flood events.

The Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team seeks funds to organize its annual Volunteer Appreciation Picnic. The funds will cover the costs of printing and mailing invitations, small thank-you gifts, and food. The Indiana County Parks Department is donating the use of their Pine Ridge Lodge for the event.

The Huntingdon County Conservation District, Penn State Cooperative Extension Service, and the Natural Resource Conservation Service are collaborating on a field day for livestock producers planning to develop or improve their grazing systems and farms looking to make a transition to no-till farming. The tour will feature a pasture walk  at the Byron Hawthorne Farm. There will also be presentations on cover crop and no-till farming by the PA No-Till Alliance and a grazing segment by the NRCS Grazing Specialist.

The Mountain Watershed Association, in partnership with the Fayette County Conservation District, seeks funding to support the 9th Annual Fayette County Children’s Water Festival. This is a day-long educational event that features more than thirty exhibits, two keynote presentations, and teaches participants the basics of water by using hands-on, creative techniques in a lively, outdoor, atmosphere.

The Pennsylvania Land Trust Association (PALTA) seeks funding to support its efforts to convene meetings of land trusts and other conservation organizations to address the proposed development of electric transmission lines. These lines may result in benefits to coal-fired generation plants and harm surrounding communities. Participants will also explore environmentally friendly alternatives.

The Penn State College of Agricultural Sciences seeks funding in support of the Conewango Creek Collaborative Conservation Initiative. The funds will be used to organize meetings throughout the Conewango watershed as a part of the community roll-out of this initiative.

The Pennsylvania Organization for Watersheds and Rivers seeks funding to support the implementation of membership development activities outlined in its recent strategic plan. Funding would be used to support general communication and in-person meetings with its membership, monitoring groups, and the general public.

The Somerset Conservation District, in partnership with the Paint Creek Watershed Association, seeks funding to support the Annual Somerset County Watershed Summit. Each year, the summit provides an opportunity for members of watershed associations, conservation organizations, and state agencies to network with other local organizations accomplishing good works. These funds would be used to rent a bus for the two-hour tour of the Paint Creek watershed and a catered dinner in Winder for those attending.

The Herron Avenue Corridor Coalition/Wesley AME Charities seeks funding to support the abandoned mine drainage geothermal system deployed at the John Wesley AME Zion Church. These funds would contribute toward the continuation of collaborative efforts with stakeholders, government agencies, and the community.

The Bertch-Hokendauqua-Catasauqua Watershed Association (BHCWA) seeks funding to be administered through the Northampton County Conservation District to apply for nonprofit, charitable organization status. This status will enable BHCWA to accept tax-deductible donations, obtain liability insurance and apply for grants to fund watershed restoration projects and education programs.

The Coal Country Hang-Out Youth Center seeks funding to initiate a course in environmental education for high school students. The course would be designed to introduce potential careers based on environmental needs and concerns in the coal-mining region.

The Citizens Coal Council seeks funding to cover the travel costs of Attorney Walt Morris to review the Enlow Fork mining permit. The purpose of review is to determine what information is in the Enlow Fork permit file and whether a proper Comprehensive Hydrologic Impact Assessment was done.

The Citizens Coal Council seeks funding to cover conference calls, travel, and staff time to continue its role in coordinating Pennsylvania coalfield groups as well as national groups to strategize ways in which they can demand the Department of the Interior to fully enforce SMCRA.

The Friends of Raystown Lake seek funding to support an AmeriCorps position for the Army Corps of Engineers at Raystown Lake. The person selected for the position will work with the biology and forestry staffs to insure water quality goals are met including: proper planning of forest management activities, erosion control planning and compliance, assistance with shoreline protection, native planting in riparian areas and monitoring of agricultural activities.

The Huntingdon County Conservation District seeks funding to cover the costs of project administration, oversight, and reporting for surface water assessments in the Juniata River. The goal of the project is to perform extensive sampling on four tributaries within the Juniata River Basin: Emma’s Creek, Fox Run, Hungary Hollow Run, and Robinson Run. Prior to this grant, none of the sites were being sampled.

As part of the watershed outreach through the Susquehanna River Heartland Coalition for Environmental Studies, Dr. Brian Mangan, a professor at King’s College, is conducting a graduate course for K-12 teachers on Chesapeake Bay Ecology. Funding is sought to defray the costs of room, board, and travel expenses for teachers attending this week-long course

Lycoming College seeks funding to host the Susquehanna River Heartland Coalition’s Marcellus Shale Science Summit. These funds would cover the costs of the various office supplies, travel expenses for the speakers, and a portion of the lunch costs.

The Pennsylvania Association for Sustainable Agriculture (PASA) seeks funding to create a field day on the general subject of “Restorative Forestry.” The event is part of the general outreach program of PASA.

The Pennsylvania Association for Sustainable Agriculture (PASA) seeks funding to support its 2010 conference entitled “Farming for the Future.” These funds will help PASA transform agriculture and food systems in the Chesapeake Bay watershed by bringing farmers, producers, educators, consumers, and community leaders together to create a viable agriculture with systems that improve the land and restore the health and wellbeing of local communities.

The Pennsylvania Council of Trout Unlimited seeks funding to help with organizing and facilitating a statewide strategic planning meeting and training for Pennsylvania’s 52 Trout Unlimited Chapters. The training will focus on finding and retaining volunteers and developing action plans for dealing with local environmental issues. This event is expected to draw about 60 participants.

The Pennsylvania Land Trust seeks funding to support their 8th Annual Pennsylvania Land Conservation Conference. This event will provide attendees with the opportunity to harness innovative tools and foster new relationships.

The Keystone Conservation Trust seeks funding to help nonprofit organizations develop data on total revenues that outdoor recreation and natural system services provide to local economies. This data will be used to help local municipal officials make better decisions on prospective development  proposals that impact natural systems.
seller_address: 336 King of Prussia Rd., Radnor, PA, 19087

properties.grant_description: The Somerset Conservation District seeks funding to complete the field work required to finalize a Somerset County Benthic Entomological Base Line Survey. This is a county wide baseline assessment of the macroinvertebrate communities in Somerset County's major watersheds. This assessment will allow for better planning of future stream improvement projects and supply volunteer organizations with standardized data and collection methods for future surveys. The project will create a technical guide as well as a recreational booklet utilizing the data collected.

The Somerset Conservation District seeks funding for the creation of a Flight 93 Corridor Conservation Priority Map. The project is recommended for implementation in the Flight 93 Nation Memorial Travel Corridor Study. This GIS generated Conservation Priority Map will document and show all of the environmentally important land and water resources as well as historic sites and other features within the corridor.

The Southwest Project Grass Chapter seeks funding for the purchase of materials used to teach proper grazing management. The grazing stick gives grazing starting heights and removal heights for different grass species and can be used to estimate pasture yields to allow for planning of grazing times and rotations. The dairy and beef grazing notebooks offer a wealth of information about grazing and provide a means for keeping grazing records.

Stream Restoration, Inc. seeks funding in support of the 2009 Ohio River Watershed Celebration. The theme for this year’s event is “The Ohio River Watershed - Fuel for a Nation.” As always, the event is free of charge to the public .

The Susquehanna River Basin Commission (SRBC) has developed a proposal to remotely monitor water quality conditions in an effort to maintain and protect smaller rivers and streams in select portions of the Susquehanna watershed. SRBC seeks funding to engage a range of governmental and non-governmental partners to secure funding, starting with a meeting to convene prospective partners.

The Western Pennsylvania Conservancy seeks funding to convene meetings and conference calls related to Phase II of a statewide campaign to secure significant funding to compensate Growing Greener funds that are quickly being depleted.

Art Works in Johnstown is a facility that offers space to artists where they can create, teach, and sell their art. Art Works is committed to conserving and enhancing its urban setting, including the riparian area of its parking lot and location. The Green Roof Project is the third phase of the Artworks program and aims to enhance and protect ecosystems and biodiversity, improve air and water quality, reduce solid waste, and conserve natural resources.

The Chesapeake Bay Funders Network Agricultural Initiative Program brings together collective talents, energy and resources of many different foundations, farmers, and technical experts. The purpose of this effort is to improve the economic sustainability of the Chesapeake’s agricultural community, while advancing the restoration of the Chesapeake Bay and its rivers.

Muddy Run is one of the most severely polluted streams within the Clearfield Creek drainage. The purpose of this project is to obtain aerial photographs of the entire Muddy Run watershed and topographic mapping of selected portions of the watershed. This information is needed to support efficient remediation efforts put into place to improve the overall water quality of the tributaries.

ClearWater Conservancy is seeking support to expand their Riparian Conservation Program initiatives into the Fishing Creek watershed. Specifically, the Little Fishing Creek watershed as it is classified as a high-quality coldwater fishery, with the upper section supporting a Class A Wild Brook Trout population. Stream assessments have determined agricultural runoff is the stream's primary threat. Expansion of the program will allow the Conservancy to target restoration initiatives on impaired and degraded stream sections.

The Environmental Integrity Project’s (EIP) Coal Combustion Waste (CCW) Project is an effort to convince the Department of Environmental Protection to issue enforceable CCW regulations rather than simple guidance documents. This is a continuation of previous work done through grants to the Clean Air Task Force. Jeff Stant, the project leader, is now an employee of EIP. EIP also hopes to create an effective grassroots advocacy network in the state that unites national environmental groups, local community groups, and private citizens. EIP seeks funding to support this project and to cover the costs of the travel, time, and expenses of staff to attend meetings and hearings and for staff time for advocacy and negotiation. 
See Documents below for regulatory process and outcomes.
properties.grant_name: PA Coal Ash Rules and Regulations

properties.grant_description: The Juniata Clean Water Partnership (JCWP) was given the directive to help partners implement the Juniata River Management Plan. Nearly a decade has passed since the completion of this plan and JCWP is interested in revisiting the plan to ensure it continues to be a living document. The project would provide necessary revisions, document accomplishment, and set forth a course of action for the coming five years.

Program funds are needed to support the ongoing efforts of the Kiski-Conemaugh Stream Team. These efforts include: monitoring of water quality parameters within the Kiski-Conemaugh River Basin as they relate to mine degradation, AMD treatment system design, and AMD treatment system function (sampling treatment system discharge points).

Rivers Conservation Plans (RCP) are the primary tool for planning river conservation activities in Pennsylvania. The Pennsylvania Organization for Watersheds and Rivers proposes to evaluate, assess, and consolidate the RCPs - including: associated documents, recommendations and strategies - in order to better understand and improve the effectiveness of implementation efforts.

The Susquehanna Greenway will be Pennsylvania’s largest greenway and will help protect the river that provides drinking water to nearly one million Pennsylvanians and more than half of the fresh water entering the Chesapeake Bay. The Susquehanna Greenway Partnership is seeking funding to support two Office of Surface Mining VISTA positions to assist them and the West Branch Susquehanna Restoration Coalition with education and outreach programming on abandoned mine drainage (AMD), greenways and trails, and in developing a volunteer stewardship network on the West Branch Susquehanna River.

The Technical Assistance for Pennsylvania’s Watersheds and Wetlands Initiative is designed to facilitate and expedite the protection and restoration of aquatic systems in critical watersheds within Pennsylvania. The Trust for Conservation Lands (TCL) proposes to deliver targeted wetland restoration to improve water quality within focus watersheds. TCL will employ the USDA Wetland Reserve Program as their primary vehicle to achieve program goals.

The story of Pennsylvania agriculture is expansive, complex and vital. For more than three hundred years, farming in the state has had an indelible influence on the science, process and culture of farming in the United States. In addition, Pennsylvania farmers continue to make significant contributions to American agriculture as it evolves in the 21st century. This seminal legacy is chronicled and celebrated in WVIA’s ambitious original documentary film Hearth and Harvest. The one-hour high-definition presentation cinematically juxtaposes history and heritage with contemporary practices and issues to convey the chance, challenge and culture of farming in the Keystone State. From seed to sprawl, from topography to tax credits, from Guernseys to global warming and boom or bust, Hearth and Harvest travels throughout the state to discover the state of farming in Pennsylvania today.

Burning coal for energy creates coal ash, an abundant waste containing levels of arsenic, lead, mercury, and other toxic metals. Despite its hazards, coal-combustion wastes are not subject to federal regulation. State laws governing coal-ash disposal are usually weak or nonexistent. Across the country, millions of tons of coal ash are stored in precarious surface impoundments, unlined landfills, and abandoned mines. The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has long recognized the dangers of coal ash and is currently considering regulatory  approaches. Earthjustice is pushing the EPA to act quickly to protect public health and the environment.

The Environmental Integrity Project’s (EIP) Coal Combustion Waste (CCW) Project is an effort to convince the Department of Environmental Protection to issue enforceable CCW regulations rather than simple guidance documents and create an effective grassroots advocacy network in the state that unites national environmental groups, local community groups, and private citizens. EIP seeks funding to support this project and to cover the costs of the travel, time, and expenses of staff to attend meetings and hearings and for staff time for advocacy and negotiation.
In light of the December 22, 2008 disaster at Kingston, TN resulting in the largest water pollution event in the history of the United States a report was produced titled "In Harms Way: Lack of Federal Coal Ash Regulations Endangers Americans and their Environment." To see the full report, visit: http://www.environmentalintegrity.org/news_reports/08_26_10.php
The Indiana County Conservation District seeks funding to supplement the compensation of two OSM/VISTA positions. Both individuals are part of the Appalachian Coal Country Watershed Team.

Local stakeholders, including the fire department, have negotiated a land transfer for an AMD treatment system. The system was awarded a $417,000 Growing Greener design and construction grant. Foundation funds were used to conduct a geothermal feasibility study. This study concluded treatment system's mine water could heat and cool the company's new fire hall. Station construction is funded via an ARRA FEMA grant.
seller_address: PO Box 33, Six Mile Run, PA, 16679

properties.grant_description: The Citizens Coal Council will be facilitating a conference call with more than twenty-one organizations and individuals to map out a plan that will ensure that a thorough list of mining issues are covered and comments are submitted to the Office of Surface Mining.

Moraine Preservation Fund is known as the organization that has been involved in the acquisition of nearly 800 acres of land to be added to the park. This particular project is for the continuation of acquisition work to protect Muddy Creek to the east of Moraine State Park. In-holdings for 6 acres within the park came up for sale within a short time frame and in order to add these sites to the park action needed to be taken quickly.
properties.grant_name: Critical Lands Addition - Moraine State Park

properties.grant_description: Having been named by the Nature Conservancy as one of there "Last Great Places" due to its biodiversity, the French Creek Project was initiated by the PA Environmental Council and the Western PA Conservancy in order to preserve its natural heritage. An emphasis will be placed on riparian restoration to abate sediment loadings into French Creek and its tributaries.

Passive treatment systems for acid mine drainage abatement are an emerging technology and this group has embarked upon an ambitious engineering project which is anoxic in design and will restore 7 miles of stream to biological function. This series of passive treatment systems are actually the creation of wetlands located underground where a layer of crushed limestone raises pH, causing heavy metals to drop out and be captured by a layer of mushroom compost.

An old farm mine exists on donated property to Powder Mill Nature Reserve. This small discharge produces some of the most acidic, toxic water assessed in western PA. Previous settling ponds designed by Penn State University are no longer functional. These funds will be used to design a treatment system that will restore 4 miles of Laurel Run which runs into White Oak Run and on to Powder Mill Run.
The intent of this project is to improve 7 miles of Chartiers Creek by combining several discharges into one passive treatments system.

The French Creek Project is embarking upon an outreach program to supplement agricultural BMPs in the watershed. Since sediment loadings are the greatest threat to the biological diversity that this watershed supports, it is thought that this initiative is an important watershed preservation element.

Continuation of BMPs to prevent agricultural sediments from entering the stream will enhance water quality to preserve water quality for which this watershed is known. There are numerous opportunities within this watershed to develop an ecotourism model for the state. Raising awareness about Ernst Nursery propagating native species is of benefit to all program grantees.

Fencing livestock from streams should be a goal of all conservation district offices. This supplemental project provides lower costs to landowners willing to participate in installing livestock crossings and streambank fencing.

Use of native plants rather than ornamentals is a new concept in rapidly developing watershed. Use of the office facility for a rain garden demonstration project meets the intent of this organization. Implementation of riparian protection at other sites will be completed with this grant.

The French Creek Project is in full-swing with their Ecotourism and River sojourn for the creek. Ag BMPs are being supplemented by agency programs including land acquisition and streambank fencing. Use of a local factory site for environmental eduction and species identification has begun under the guidance of the project.

The Neshannock Creek Chapter of Trout Unlimited seeks funding for an ongoing project of water and land monitoring. Part of the scope of work includes streambank fencing and stabilization as a suitable area for a demonstration project. The goal is to reduce siltation and to demonstrate the value of this practice through teaching quality control and water monitoring. THere is a credible advisory group made up of community members who have agreed to serve a one year term and meet quarterly to review project purposes and activities and to advise Neshannock Creek volunteers.

PA Cleanways, the Juniata Clean Water Parntership, and the Huntingdon County Conservation District are requesting funds to clean up several streamside dumps and to form a new county chapter. This grant would support two major cleanup activities, insurance, signage, organizational consultation, promotional and educational materials, publications, and administrative support.

The goal of this project is to enhance the upper reaches of Skinner Creek, including a section of fenced streambank and the replanting of a riparian zone. The group has a history of success in streambank stabilization and the new scope of work includes a 1700 foot section of creek that was recently purchased by the Game Commission. This public land is two miles from downtown Port Allegheny and is not only visible, but is very accessible to the general public. This section of stream has qualified for a Class A wild brown trout classification.

This grant, administered by the Southern Alleghenies Conservancy, is to help the Quemahoning Watershed Association complete a small SAPS (Successive Alkalinity Producing System) to accompany the larger Boswell Passive Treatment System.  The addition of this designed small system to be added to the network of large installations will complete the work for the abatement of acid mine drainage in the Boswell area.  Also requested in the proposal is use of a portion of funds for the construction of permanent signs at both the Jenners and Boswell sites to explain and inform visitors about the projects and list all partners involved.  The Quemahoning Creek Project has an array of partners including the Mountain Laurel Chapter of Trout Unlimited, the Stonycreek/Conemaugh River Improvement Project, and the Jenner Joint Water Authority.  The Jenner Rod and Gun Club donated $25,000 for the purchase of the site for the Boswell Passive Treatment System.  The PA DEP, Bureau of Abandoned Mine Reclamation has provided the funding.  The scope of this project through agency funding is over $200,000.

Located five miles south of Mount Union, Aughwick Creek is a tributary of the Juniata River.  The grant was made to purchase native plants, root wads, and live stakes for this steam bank stabilization project along two hundred linear feet of eroded bank, which is steep and undercut. The total cost of the project was $9,500 and Canaan Valley Institute was the largest funding entity.  The finished demonstration project is expected to serve as a model for future works in the area.   There has been much interest from property owners, local officials, and individuals interested in alternatives to riprap for stream bank stabilization. The Youth Forestry Camp and the Juniata Clean Water Partnership provided volunteer hours. All involved agreed they would do it again. The most interesting feature of this project is the habitat that has been created as a result, especially to muskrats and minks.

Utilizing a new design of a second generation SAPS (Successive Alkalinity Producing System), this project will remediate the worst discharge on Shade Creek.  Site 16 at Central City is the largest of 270 coal mine discharges in the Stonycreek River Basin.  What is interesting about this project is that through the Resource Recovery Study evaluating metal loadings of the 101 worst discharges in Pennsylvania's Bituminous coal fields it was determined that this site ranked fifth in aluminum load.  The site is constrained by its geography and it is estimated that the remediation technique will produce 100 tons of dry weight aluminum annually.  The grant from the Pennsylvania Watershed Protection Program accompanies an $80,000 grant through the Office of Surface Mining.  Selecting for this one resource alone it is estimated that this installation will reduce by more than 10% the amount of pollution entering the Stonycreek River.

This project will re-establish the riparian buffer along 630 feet that would exist naturally along the stream.  The buffer will act as a living filter where sediments and agricultural chemicals, as well as fertilizers are trapped and utilized by the plant material.  Roots of the woody vegetation will also slow the velocity of runoff during high flows reducing stream bank erosion and promoting groundwater recharge.  All buffers will be based on the three-zone concept endorsed by the USDA and EPA.  Zone 1, undisturbed forest, Zone 2 managed forests, Zone 3 grassed transition area.  Project area A will be fast track, using 11/2" diameter native low land trees to quickly establish the buffer zone.  Also included in the area will be under story trees, shrubs, and grasses.  Project area B, C and D will use existing native plants as well as small 2-3 ft. trees with under story seeded with a native woody plant seed mix.  A grass filter strip will be seeded as well.  Leverage in this case is the volunteer core put together by Brian Hill, leader of the French Creek Project.

Progress toward full inventory of fresh water mussels and clams is progressing with the intent to monitor any invasive species, such as the zebra mussel. It is a hope of the Project that when watershed restoration is completed that the biology of the French Creek Project can someday be transplanted to those watersheds from which they have been extirpated. Agricultural BMPs continue to be a part of this effort.

This Trout Unlimited Chapter is completing a streamside stabilization/riparian buffer corridor improvement along Pine Creek, Allegheny County, PA.  The ultimate goal of the project is to complete the above conservation measure to reduce and/or eliminate further erosion and sedimentation problems occurring to the stream channel, thus improving water quality in Pine Creek.  Efforts will be concentrated on the planting and stabilization of a 1/4-mile stretch of stream above a designated Delayed Harvest stretch of stream.  Roessing Bronze once occupied this section, where several settling ponds and a large building were present.  Currently, the property is devoid of any structures and the land is now barren.  This stretch of stream was identified by Mr. Mike Wheale, of the PFBC, as being one of the worst stretches with regard to sedimentation and increased temperature.  The total cost of the project was $27,772.50.

The purpose of this grant is for continuing research and monitoring relative to the application of composted chicken manure on abandoned mine lands. In addition to the original demonstration plan to use hybrid poplar trees, this project will also investigate the use of switchgrass for biomass production.

The purpose of this grant is to continue the documentation of the impact of the invasion of the asian clams and zebra mussels in the Susquehanna River. This project will study how these species affect the ecology of the River, particularly the organisms that inhabit the river bottom.

This grant covers three projects for Lycoming College. The first project will focus on the continuation of monitoring the waters of Lycoming Creek and lake sites within the region. Work will also continue on the riparian planting project at Montour Preserve. The second project will work on the development of an economically efficient waste water treatment system for use in rural areas without conventional sewer systems and where discharges negatively impact water sources. The third project will study the health and stability of the Eastern Hellbender salamander populations and assess the possible causes of declines observed in some local tributary streams. Assessment of stream physical, chemical, and biological characteristics will be made to determine if habitat loss, water quality, and/or food depletion are contributing factors.

Susquehanna University will use this grant for three projects. The first is to continue the study of terrestrial vertebrates at two permanent sites. Students will also study two species of owls that use both the Susquehanna River basin and the Chillisquaque Creek and reservoir. The second project will continue the study of Shamokin Creek and monitoring the water chemistry of the creek, particularly those elements that are characteristic with abandoned mine drainage. The third project is to better understand how to treat AMD and the relationship of biological, chemical, and hydrological processes.

This grant will be used to continue the monitoring of the Bureau of Abandoned Mine Reclamation's passive treatment system along the West Branch of the Susquehanna River. Work done on this project, including data collection and laboratory analysis will serve to determine the effectiveness of the system.
seller_address: 401 N. Fairview St., Lock Haven, PA, 17745

properties.grant_description: Bucknell University will use this grant to study the atmospheric acid deposition impact on the headwaters of Buffalo Creek and to work on a wetlands restoration project at the Central Builders gravel quarry in Montandon. Students will develop a water budget of the site, including groundwater and surface water interactions. A nursery and revegetation plan using indigenous wetland plants will be developed.

This grant will be used to study the impact of abandoned mine drainage on stream organisms with an emphasis on determining the effects of AMD on bird communities along Shamokin Creek. Monies will also be used to edit and publish the second issue of "Watershed: The Journal of the Susquehanna." This publication chronicles the Susquehanna River Watershed with articles from writers throughout the watershed, including watershed groups, conservancies, and colleges and universities.
The purpose of this grant is to provide funding support for application toward water monitoring equipment.
This purpose of this grant is to provide funding support for an application to Susquehanna University's mercury analyzer.
The purpose of this grant is to provide funding support for application to Lycoming College's summer 2008 stipend.
The purpose of this grant is to be used for operations, maintenance and repair of Scarlift Site #15, also know as the Corbin Drift Mine.

The PA Environmental Council seeks funding to further advance their agricultural, stormwater management, and conservation partnership work in the Upper Allegheny region, including the French Creek Watershed. Specific initiatives to be implemented this year are agricultural land conservation through value-added product development, direct market opportunities, rural economic development, stormwater planning, best management practices and outreach, Upper Allegheny conservation partnerships, and Great Lakes policy and planning.

Program funds are needed to support the ongoing monitoring of water quality parameters within the Kiski-Conemaugh River Basin as they relate to mine degradation, AMD treatment system design, and AMD treatment system function. Additionally, the Stream Team is working with Indiana University of PA and Westmoreland County Penn State Cooperative Extension to explore the possibility of gathering data on organic compounds in Basin waterways. These compounds can bioaccumulate in aquatic species and can have human health affects. The Stream Team educates, trains, and coordinates volunteers to be sure they collect water samples according to PA DEP protocols.

Site conditions coupled with landowner transfers and reduced construction time resulted in system flaws with the Morgan Run treatment system. Currently, several aggregated discharges are being directed into a vertical flow pond that was not designed to treat current iron levels. The increased iron loading is quickly filling compost void space resulting in a diminished life expectancy of the system. The solution calls for a channel to be built which will direct the high pH and low iron water directly into a settling pond.

Rhiza Labs will create a design website for watershed projects that is both information-rich, yet accessible and usable. Rhiza will work with the staff of FPW to discuss and prioritize database needs from which Rhiza will create an appropriate data model and design approach for capturing and broadcasting data of interest about Foundation projects.

The Chesapeake Bay Funders Network has collaborated to develop a watershed-wide agricultural initiative that is bringing the collective talents, energy, and resources of multiple foundations, nonprofit organizations, technical experts, and farmers to protect the Chesapeake Bay and its tributary rivers.
properties.grant_name: Strong Communities, Healthy Waters Agricultural Initiative

properties.grant_description: The Six Mile Run Area Watershed Committee seeks funding to support their annual Watershed Festival. The festival will bring together several nonprofit groups and agencies to meet with students and the general public to celebrate the watershed.
seller_address: 187 Municpal Rd. PO Box 57, Defiance, PA, 16633

properties.grant_description: The Slippery Rock Watershed Coalition (SRWC) is requesting funding to convert its popular publication, "Accepting the Challenge: A primer about the history, cause, and solutions to abandoned mine drainage" to digital format. This effort will expand the publication's distribution and make it more affordable and accessible to households and classrooms. Your digital copy is available at: http://www.srwc.org/resources/atc/.

This year's awards will support the development of Coldwater Conservation Plans for Aquetong Creek (Bucks County), Hells Run (Lawrence County), Hunts Run (Cameron County), Moshannon Creek (Clearfield County), N. Branch Bear Run (Indiana County), Rogues Harber Run (Clearfield and Cambria Counties), Upper Spring Creek (Centre County), and Tea Creek (Mifflin County).
The mission of the Coldwater Heritage Partnership Program (CHP) is to protect the health and productivity of the state's most outstanding coldwater ecosystems. We do this by providing leadership, coordination and assistance to organizations focused on the conservation and protection of PA’s coldwater streams and our wild trout populations.
The CHP program is a cooperative initiative of the PA DCNR, PA Fish and Boat Commission, PA Trout (A Council of Trout Unlimited) and the Foundation for Pennsylvania Watersheds.
Goals of the Coldwater Heritage Partnership Program:
1. Foster a greater public understanding of watershed characteristics as they affect coldwater ecosystems.
2. Build partnerships that improve the ability to protect our headwater resources.
3. Identify, understand and protect areas of special interest, such as coldwater ecosystems that exhibit high quality or exceptional value with a high potential for impacts or areas that can be of exceptional or high quality if restored.
For additional information about the Coldwater Heritage Partnership, please visit www.coldwaterheritage.org

This year's awards will support Coldwater Conservation Plans for Beech Creek (Centre and Clinton Counties), Clearshade, Piney, and Cub Run (Somerset County), Laurel Run (Somerset County), Little Lehigh Creek (Lehigh and Berks Counties), Mill Creek (Berks County), Schoolhouse Run (Jefferson County), Spring Creek (Warren County), and Williams Run (Venango and Mercer Counties).

The Six Mile Run Area Watershed Committee, the Broad Top Township Supervisors, and the Tussey Mountain School District are sponsoring a watershed festival on March 20, 2010 at the Six Mile Run Fire Hall. The festival will bring together nonprofit groups and agencies to meet with the general public and students. This event celebrates the watershed improvements made so far and recognizes problems still to be solved. The festival promises to be an enjoyable community event and a great educational experience. Attendance at this year's event is expected to exceed 700 students.
seller_address: 187 Municpal Rd. PO Box 57, Defiance, PA, 16633

properties.grant_description: The Western Pennsylvania Conservancy's "Better Roads, Cleaner Streams" program implements road improvement projects on dirt and gravel roads. These funds will contribute toward work in Bedford and Fulton Counties and will address sedimentation of headwater streams in the Potomac River watershed. This program will not only benefit the Potomac River watershed, but also the Chesapeake Bay. Additionally, local and state roads departments will be able to complete road improvement projects, and local residents will enjoy better roads with fewer maintenance problems.
